definitionA: having or showing little or no emotion:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Void of feeling; not susceptible of deep emotion
   2. Of, or pertaining to apatheism.
etymology: First recorded in 1735–45; apath(y) + (path)etic
example: Both were victims because they were too apathetic to find a better place to leave their equipment.

definitionA: a pustule on the body in an eruptive disease, as smallpox.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A pus-filled swelling on the surface on the skin caused by an eruptive disease.
   2. Any pit, especially one formed as a scar
<verb>
   1. To scar or mark with pits
etymology: before 1000; Middle English pokke, Old English poc; cognate with German Pocke; perhaps akin to Old English pocca. See poke 2
example: The pock-marked ridges in the distance are covered with the advancing waves of field-grey forms.

definitionA: to give vigor to; fill with life and energy; energize.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To impart vigor, strength, or vitality to.
   2. To heighten or intensify.
   3. To give life or energy to.
   4. To make lively.
etymology: First recorded in 1640–50; in- 2 + obsolete vigorate “invigorated”; vigor, -ate 1
example: It has been invigorating and fun to be active again, and increased my confidence.

definitionA: disapproval; condemnation.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An act or expression of condemnation or disapproval, especially on moral grounds.
etymology: First recorded in 1640–50; dis- 1 + approbation
example: He did this to signalise his disapprobation of royalty, and his preference for democratic equality.

definitionA: a lover of words.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. One who loves words; a word buff.
etymology: logo- + -phile

definitionA: a military encampment made with tents or improvised shelters, usually without shelter or protection from enemy fire.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An encampment for the night, usually without tents or covering.
   2. Any temporary encampment.
   3. A temporary shelter constructed generally for a few nights.
   4. The watch of a whole army by night, when in danger of surprise or attack.
   5. A structure formed by migratory ants out of their own bodies to protect the queen and larvae.
<verb>
   1. To set up camp.
   2. To watch at night or be on guard, as a whole army.
   3. To encamp for the night without tents or covering.
etymology: 1700–10; < French < Swiss German bīwacht auxiliary patrol, equivalent to bī- by- + wacht patrol, watch
example: Our airy bivouac, our fourth on the mountain, didn’t have an additional centimeter of space on any side.

definitionA: to keep watch.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To oversee a test or exam.
etymology: 1545–55; < Latin invigilātus (past participle of invigilāre to keep watch, stay up late), equivalent to in- in- 2 + vigilā- (stem of vigilāre to watch; vigil ) + -tus past participle suffix
example: A judicial inquiry, however, has power to gather evidence, to summon the trio, and invigilate them properly and professionally.

definitionA: a signal, as of a drum or bugle, sounded early in the morning to awaken military personnel and to alert them for assembly.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The sounding of a bugle or drum early in the morning to awaken soldiers.
etymology: 1635–45; < French réveillez, plural imperative of réveiller to awaken, equivalent to r ( e ) - re- + éveiller, Old French esveillier ≪ Latin ēvigilāre to watch, be vigilant ( ē- e- 1 + vigilāre to watch; vigil )
example: The school is currently on Reveille VIII, and all iterations have been female.

definitionA: to carry lightly and smoothly through the air or over water:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A light breeze.
   2. Something (such as an odor or scent like a perfume) that is carried through the air.
   3. A flag used to indicate wind direction or, with a knot tied in the center, as a signal; a waif, a wheft.
<verb>
   1. To (cause to) float easily or gently through the air.
   2. To be moved, or to pass, on a buoyant medium; to float.
   3. To give notice to by waving something; to wave the hand to; to beckon.
etymology: 1535–45; back formation from late Middle English waughter armed escort vessel < Dutch or Low German wachter watchman; in some senses confused with waff
example: In dark pockets of the universe, molecular clouds full of tiny dust particles host a veritable smorgasbord of odors, from wafts of sweet sugar to the rotten-egg stench of sulfur.

definitionA: a batter cake with a pattern of deep indentations on each side, formed by the gridlike design on each of the two hinged parts of the metal appliance waffle iron in which the cake is baked.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A flat pastry pressed with a grid pattern.
   2. A potato waffle, a savoury flat potato cake with the same kind of grid pattern.
<verb>
   1. To smash.
<noun>
   1. Speech or writing that is vague, pretentious or evasive.
<verb>
   1. (of birds) To move in a side-to-side motion and descend (lose altitude) before landing. Cf wiffle, whiffle.
   2. To speak or write vaguely and evasively.
   3. To speak or write at length without any clear point or aim.
   4. To vacillate.
   5. To rotate (one's hand) back and forth in a gesture of vacillation or ambivalence.
etymology: First recorded in 1735–45; from Dutch wafel; wafer ( def )
example: It’s designed to look as no-nonsense as it performs, and it makes hefty 4-slice Belgian waffles with adjustable browning controls to ensure you get the precise mix of crispy and spongy.

definitionA: an important food fish, Clupea harengus harengus, found in enormous shoals in the North Atlantic.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A type of small, oily fish of the genus Clupea, often used as food.
   2. Fish in the family Clupeidae.
   3. Fish similar to those in genus Clupea, many of those in the order Clupeiformes.
etymology: before 900; Middle English hering, Old English hǣring; cognate with German Häring
example: With the red herring out of the way, XENONnT researchers are now combing through their data for nuclear recoils, in hopes of detecting the real deal.

definitionA: Law. pertaining to, of the nature of, or involving a felony:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Of, relating to, being, or having the quality of felony
   2. Done with intent to commit a crime.
etymology: 1375–1425; felony + -ous; replacing late Middle English felonous < Anglo-French, Old French
example: Miettinen has an arrest record that includes 13 prior offenses, including felonious assault with a deadly weapon, aggravated assault, reckless driving, and disobeying a police officer.

definitionA: to confuse or mix up:
definitionB: No definition found
etymology: From Pennsylvania Dutch verhuddle “to tangle, confuse”; compare German verhudeln “to bungle, botch”

definitionA: to make rare or rarer; make less dense:
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To make rare, thin, porous, or less dense
   2. To expand or enlarge without adding any new portion of matter to.
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; Middle English rarefien, from Middle French rarefier, from Medieval Latin rārificāre, from Latin rārēfacere, equivalent to rārē-, irregular, unexplained combining form of rārus + facere “to make”; rare 1, -fy
example: Would an atmosphere perfumed by these Eastern woods clarify and rarefy our denser Occidental minds?

definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An order to the contrary of a previous one.
<verb>
   1. To revoke (a former command); to cancel or rescind by giving an order contrary to one previously given.
   2. To recall a person or unit with such an order.
   3. To prohibit.
   4. To oppose; to revoke the command of.

definitionA: a parchment or the like from which writing has been partially or completely erased to make room for another text.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A manuscript or document that has been erased or scraped clean, for reuse of the paper, parchment, vellum, or other medium on which it was written.
   2. Monumental brasses that have been reused by engraving of the blank back side.
   3. Circular features believed to be lunar craters that have been obliterated by later volcanic activity.
   4. Geological features thought to be related to features or effects below the surface.
   5. Memory that has been erased and re-written.
   6. (cultural studies) The partial erasure of or superimposition on an older society or culture by a newer one.
   7. Something bearing the traces of an earlier, erased form.
<verb>
   1. To scrape clean, as in parchment, for reuse.
   2. On paper: to reuse, often by erasure or change of pen direction or color. Especially fueled by Earth Day.
etymology: First recorded in 1655–65; from Latin palimpsēstus, from Greek palímpsēstos “rubbed again” ( pálin “again” + psēstós “scraped, rubbed,” past participle of psân “to rub smooth”)
example: Can you talk about how the palimpsest informs the structure of your novel?

definitionA: suitable; well-adapted; pertinent; relevant; apt:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. That which is apposite; something suitable.
<adjective>
   1. Strikingly appropriate or relevant; well suited to the circumstance or in relation to something.
   2. Positioned at rest in respect to another, be it side-to-side, front-to-front, back-to-back, or even three-dimensionally: in apposition.
   3. Related, homologous.
etymology: 1615–25; < Latin appositus added to, put near (past participle of appōnere ), equivalent to ap- ap- 1 + positus placed ( posi- place + -tus past participle suffix)
example: These remarks, as will appear in the sequel, are apposite to the parties which I am about to introduce to the reader.

definitionA: to speak of or treat slightingly; depreciate; belittle:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Inequality in marriage; marriage with an inferior.
<verb>
   1. To match unequally; to degrade or dishonor.
   2. To dishonor by a comparison with what is inferior; to lower in rank or estimation by actions or words; to speak slightingly of; to depreciate; to undervalue.
   3. To ridicule, mock, discredit.
etymology: First recorded in 1250–1300; Middle English, from Anglo-French, Old French desparag(i)er “to match unequally,” from des- dis- 1 + -parag(i)er, verb derivative of parage “equal rank,” also “high birth, noble descent” ( peerage )
example: The company has also held ongoing mandatory meetings for workers on company time, so-called captive-audience sessions, to show videos and run through PowerPoint presentations that disparage unionization.

definitionA: a gap or missing part, as in a manuscript, series, or logical argument; hiatus.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A small opening; a small pit or depression.
   2. A small blank space; a gap or vacancy; a hiatus.
   3. An absent part, especially in a book or other piece of writing, often referring to an ancient manuscript or similar.
   4. Any gap, break, hole, or lack in a set of things; something missing.
   5. A space visible between cells, allowing free passage of light.
   6. A language gap, which occurs when there is no direct translation in the target language for a lexical term found in the source language.
etymology: First recorded in 1655–65; from Latin lacūna “ditch, pit, hole, gap, deficiency,” akin to lacus “basin, tub, vat, lake”; lake 1. lagoon
example: It doesn’t seriously examine the role of scholarship at the Met, and that is a telling lacuna.

definitionA: to pay out (money), especially for expenses; expend.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To pay out, expend; usually from a public fund or treasury.
etymology: First recorded in 1520–30; from Middle French desbourser, Old French desborser, equivalent to des- dis- 1 + -borser, derivative of borse purse, from Late Latin bursa “bag”
example: It has already raised and disbursed several hundreds of thousands of dollars in grants to groups it has vetted.

definitionA: (used chiefly of viviparous mammals) the young of an animal in the womb or egg, especially in the later stages of development when the body structures are in the recognizable form of its kind, in humans after the end of the second month of gestation.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An unborn or unhatched vertebrate showing signs of the mature animal.
   2. A human embryo after the eighth week of gestation.
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; Middle English, from Latin fētus “bringing forth of young,” hence “that which is born, offspring, young still in the womb,” equivalent to fē- (verb base attested in Latin only in noun derivatives, as fēmina “woman,” fēcundus “fertile,” fīlius “son,” fīlia “daughter,” etc.; compare Greek thēsthai “to suck, milk,” Old High German tāan “to suck,” Old Irish denid “(he) sucks,” Slavic (Polish) doić “to milk” + -tus suffix of verb action; fecund
example: The incident happened at Hamad international airport in Doha earlier this month after a fetus was discovered in an airport bathroom.

definitionA: the young of a viviparous animal, especially of a mammal, in the early stages of development within the womb, in humans up to the end of the second month. Compare fetus.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. In the reproductive cycle, the stage after the fertilization of the egg that precedes the development into a fetus.
   2. An organism in the earlier stages of development before it emerges from the egg, or before metamorphosis.
   3. In viviparous animals, the young animal's earliest stages in the mother's body
   4. In humans, usually the cell growth up to the end of the seventh week in the mother's body
   5. A rudimentary plant contained in the seed.
   6. The beginning; the first stage of anything.
etymology: First recorded in 1580–90; from Medieval Latin embryo, embryon-, from Greek émbryon, noun use of neuter of émbryos “ingrowing,” equivalent to em- “in” + bry- (stem of brýein “to swell”) + -os adjective suffix; em- 2
example: A female-founded Israeli startup called Embryonics is setting out to change this by using artificial intelligence to screen embryos.

definitionA: a person who punts a boat
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. One who bets (punts) against the bank.
   2. One who oars or poles a punt (pontoon).
   3. One who punts a football.
   4. One who gambles. See speculator.
   5. A customer of a commercial establishment, frequently of a pub or (alternatively) of a prostitute.
   6. A beginner or unskilled climber.
   7. The person who keeps score in basset or ombre.
   8. A program used to forcibly disconnect another user from a network.
example: The clip below, of Mayall hamming it up when he realises a punter is filming him at a charity auction, is a classic.

definitionA: inclined to dodge.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Evasive and shifty
   2. Unsound and unreliable
   3. Dishonest
   4. Risky
   5. Deviant
   6. Uncomfortable and weird
etymology: First recorded in 1860–65; dodge + -y 1
example: When in 1803 Jefferson unconstitutionally bought Louisiana from Napoleon using a dodgy British loan, neither the Senate nor the Supreme Court stopped him.

definitionA: to present, especially deliberately, the appearance of being; profess or claim, often falsely:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Import, intention or purpose
   2. Disguise; covering
<verb>
   1. To convey, imply, or profess outwardly (often falsely).
   2. (construed with to) To intend.
etymology: First recorded in 1375–1425; (verb) late Middle English purporten, from Anglo-French purporter “to mean, signify,” Old French porporter “to carry, convey,” equivalent to pur- pro- 1 + porter “to carry” (from Latin portāre ); (noun) late Middle English, from Anglo-French, derivative of the verb
example: Ukrainian government intercepts also purport to reveal Ukrainian separatists acknowledging they controlled SA-11 systems.

definitionA: (often initial capital letter) the Apostles' Creed or the Nicene Creed.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A belief system.
   2. The liturgical creed (usually the Nicene Creed), or a musical arrangement of it for use in church services.
etymology: 1150–1200; Middle English < Latin: literally, I believe; first word of the Apostles' and Nicene Creeds in Latin
example: The unwavering credo of the reducetarian movement may well be “inclusivity” of different philosophical views.

definitionA: full of, characterized by, or due to zeal; ardently active, devoted, or diligent.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Full of zeal; ardent, fervent; exhibiting enthusiasm or strong passion.
etymology: First recorded in 1520–30; from Medieval Latin zēlōsus; zeal, -ous
example: Rather, I understood such zealous procedures as necessary security precautions.

definitionA: a shelflike sleeping space, as on a ship, airplane, or railroad car.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A fixed bunk for sleeping (in caravans, trains, etc).
   2. Room for maneuvering or safety. (Often used in the phrase a wide berth.)
   3. A space for a ship to moor or a vehicle to park.
   4. A room in which a number of the officers or ship's company mess and reside.
   5. A job or position, especially on a ship.
   6. Position or seed in a tournament bracket.
   7. Position on the field of play
<verb>
   1. To bring (a ship or vehicle) into its berth
etymology: First recorded in 1615–25; probably equivalent to bear 1 + -th 1
example: Then to close out the season, Washington returns home for meetings with Rivera’s old team, the Panthers, and the Seattle Seahawks, before heading to Philadelphia with possibly a playoff berth on the line.

definitionA: to use profanity; curse; swear.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A curse.
   2. A curse word.
<verb>
   1. To use cursing, to use bad language, to speak profanely.
<noun>
   1. A fellow, person.
etymology: An Americanism first recorded in 1765–75; variant of curse, with loss of r and shortening of vowel, as in ass 2, bass 2, passel, etc.
example: If Republicans win big, Democrats will hang their heads and cuss the Koch brothers.

definitionA: absurd or foolish talk; nonsense.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Nonsense.
<interjection>
   1. An expression of disbelief or annoyance.
<noun>
   1. The lower part of a blast furnace, between the hearth and the stack.
<noun>
   1. A figure.
<interjection>
   1. An expression of speedy and satisfactory completion of a simple or straightforward task.
<verb>
   1. To consume (illicit drugs).
etymology: 1830–35; < Turkish boş empty; popularized from its use in the novel Ayesha (1834) by British author James J. Morier (1780–1849)
example: “Somebody had to break the ice,” Bosh, whose own sexuality has been questioned in recent years, says.

definitionA: a person who is learning the letters of the alphabet.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Someone who is learning the alphabet.
   2. An elementary student, a novice; one in the early steps of learning.
   3. Someone engaged in teaching the alphabet; an elementary teacher; one that teaches the methods and principles of learning.
   4. A work which uses words or lines in alphabetical order.
<adjective>
   1. Pertaining to someone learning the alphabet or basic studies; elementary; rudimentary.
   2. Pertaining to the alphabet, or several alphabets.
   3. Arranged in an alphabetical manner.
   4. Relating to or resembling an abecedarius.
etymology: First recorded in 1595–1605; from Medieval Latin abecedāriānus; abecedary, -an
example: Perry had 123 kids from 104 families; the number in Abecedarian was even smaller.

definitionA: a small space or compartment partitioned off.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A small separate part or one of the compartments of a room, especially in a work environment.
   2. A small enclosure at a swimming pool etc. used to provide personal privacy when changing.
   3. A small enclosure in a public toilet for individual use.
etymology: 1400–50; late Middle English < Latin cubiculum bedroom, equivalent to cub ( āre ) to lie down + -i- -i- + -culum -cle 2
example: Amazon officials said the structure is intended to be an alternative workspace, not a traditional office building, where employees would be able to air out ideas and find downtime beyond their cubicles.

definitionA: the nonliving epidermis that surrounds the edges of the fingernail or toenail.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The outermost layer of the skin of vertebrates; the epidermis.
   2. The strip of hardened skin at the base and sides of a fingernail or toenail.
   3. Dead or cornified epidermis.
   4. A noncellular protective covering outside the epidermis of many invertebrates and plants.
   5. A thin skin formed on the surface of a liquid.
etymology: 1605–15; < Latin cutīcula the skin, equivalent to cuti ( s ) skin, cutis + -cula -cle 1
example: A study now finds that tiny hairs on that cuticle act as a lubricant.

definitionA: being or relating to an act, process, or period of testing, as of a person’s character, performance, qualifications, etc.:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An employee who is still in their probationary period.
<adjective>
   1. Of, pertaining to, or subject to probation
etymology: probation ( def ) + -ary ( def )
example: Facebook’s latest attempt to slow disinformation means probation for groupsFacebook offers ways to export your own profile data so you have a copy, and even a tool for moving your photos to competing services.

definitionA: (used with a plural verb) gymnastic exercises.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A sport involving the performance of sequences of movements requiring physical strength, flexibility, and kinesthetic awareness.
   2. Complex intellectual or artistic exercises or feats of physical agility.
etymology: First recorded in 1645–55; gymnastic, -ics
example: Habits die hard, and at the pool and gymnastics venues, journalists clumped together as they always had to ask questions and snag quotes when athletes stopped by.

definitionA: slang. a stupid person
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. (Eastern US) An incompetent or foolish person.
etymology: C20: from the name for the puppets used in the television programme The Muppet Show
example: Pelosi is one of many politicians who have given in to the temptation of being pictured alongside a cartoon character or Muppet.

definitionA: shedding the leaves annually, as certain trees and shrubs.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Describing a part that falls off, or is shed, at a particular time or stage of development.
   2. Of or pertaining to trees which lose their leaves in winter or the dry season.
   3. Transitory, ephemeral, not lasting.
etymology: First recorded in 1650–60; from Latin dēciduus “tending to fall, falling,” equivalent to dēcid(ere) “to fall off, down” ( dē- verb prefix of removal) + -cidere (combining form of cadere “to fall”) + -uus adjective suffix. See de-, -ous
example: This sweet spot happens in September, just before the deciduous trees start flaming all-out crimson.

definitionA: a violent, lawless, or vicious person, especially one who commits a crime such as assault, robbery, or murder:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Someone with an intimidating and unseemly appearance and mannerisms, who treats others violently and roughly, often for hire.
   2. One of a band of assassins formerly active in northern India who worshipped Kali and offered their victims to her.
   3. In gardening, an over-vigorous plant that spreads and dominates the flowerbed.
   4. A punk; a hoodlum; a hooligan.
<verb>
   1. To commit acts of thuggery, to live the life of a thug, or to dress and act in a manner reminiscent of someone who does.
etymology: First recorded in 1800–10; from Hindi, Marathi ṭhag “swindler, cheat, rogue,” perhaps from Sanskrit sthaga- “a cheat,” from sthagati “he conceals”
example: Mike has busted broncos, been tossed by bulls, alienated his former wife with his stoicism and, most recently, taken on various thugs.

definitionA: to harass (a public speaker, performer, etc.) with impertinent questions, gibes, or the like; badger.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An instrument with steel pins used to comb out flax or hemp.
   2. (usually now in the plural) One of the long, narrow feathers on the neck of birds, most noticeable on the rooster.
   3. A feather used to make a fishing lure or a fishing lure incorporating a feather.
   4. (usually now in the plural) By extension (because the hackles of a rooster are lifted when it is angry), the hair on the nape of the neck in dogs and other animals; also used figuratively for humans.
   5. A plate with rows of pointed needles used to blend or straighten hair.
   6. A feather plume on some soldier's uniforms, especially the hat or helmet.
   7. Any flimsy substance unspun, such as raw silk.
<noun>
   1. The long shining feathers on a cock's neck.
   2. A feather ornament in the full-dress bonnets of Highland regiments.
<verb>
   1. To question harshly in an attempt to find or reveal weaknesses.
   2. To insult, tease, make fun of or badger.
   3. To prepare flax for spinning using special combs called hackles
etymology: First recorded in 1275–1325; Middle English hekelen, variant of hechelen “to comb flax”; akin to hackle 1, hatchel
example: Known on stage for his confrontational style, Gelman heckles the audience as much as they heckle him.

definitionA: readily or plainly seen, heard, perceived, etc.; obvious; evident:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Capable of being touched, felt or handled; touchable, tangible.
   2. Obvious or easily perceived; noticeable.
   3. That can be detected by palpation.
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; Middle English, from Late Latin palpābilis “touchable,” from palpā(re) “to stroke, touch” ( palpate 1 ) + -bilis -ble
example: The joy of togetherness was the thing that was most missed by our students over the past months, and when the signal arrived that the vaccine was working, the yearning to gather once again was palpable.

definitionA: mist; fog.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Mist, fog, vapour.
etymology: 1800–10; < French: fog < Provençal bruma < Latin brūma winter, originally winter solstice, contraction of *brevima ( diēs ) shortest (day); breve
example: Le laid est beau et le beau laid Allons flotter dans la brume, Allons faire le tour du monde, Dans la brume et l'air immonde.

definitionA: boldly rude or disrespectful; contemptuously impertinent; insulting:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A person who is insolent.
<adjective>
   1. Insulting in manner or words.
   2. Rude.
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; Middle English from Latin insolent- (stem of insolēns ) “departing from custom,” equivalent to in- in- 3 + sol- (stem of solēre “to be accustomed”) + -ent- -ent
example: Their very posture—the way they loitered and leaned and lolled about—was insolent.

definitionA: to derive as a conclusion from something known or assumed; infer:
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To reach a conclusion by applying rules of logic to given premises.
   2. To take away; to deduct; to subtract.
   3. (Latinism) To lead forth.
etymology: First recorded in 1520–30; from Latin dēdūcere “to lead down, derive,” from dē- de- + dūcere “to lead”
example: Estimating the number of missed outbursts, the astronomers deduced the yearly nova rate.

definitionA: Phonetics, Orthography. a diacritic (˘) over a vowel to show that it is short, or to indicate a specific pronunciation, as ŭ in (kŭt) cut.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A semicircular diacritical mark (˘) placed above a vowel, commonly used to mark its quantity as short.
   2. A double whole note.
   3. Any writ or precept under seal, issued out of any court.
   4. The great ant thrush of Sumatra (Pitta gigas), which has a very short tail.
etymology: 1250–1300; Middle English < Medieval Latin, Latin breve, neuter of brevis short; brief
example: Combinations such as (y with breve and macron) or (o with under-dot and macron) may not display as intended in all browsers.

definitionA: shortness of time or duration; briefness:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The quality of being brief in duration.
   2. Succinctness; conciseness.
   3. A short piece of writing.
etymology: First recorded in 1500–10; from Anglo-French brevite, Old French brievete, from briev(e), feminine of brief brief + -ete -ity
example: We humans living on our one planet wring our hands about the brevity of our lives and our mortal restraints, but we do not often think about how improbable it is to be alive at all.

definitionA: lasting or taking a short time; of short duration:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A writ summoning one to answer to any action.
   2. An answer to any action.
   3. A memorandum of points of fact or of law for use in conducting a case.
   4. (by extension) A position of interest or advocacy.
   5. An attorney's legal argument in written form for submission to a court.
   6. (English law) The material relevant to a case, delivered by a solicitor to the barrister who tries the case.
   7. A short news story or report.
   8. (usually in the plural) undershorts briefs.
   9. A summary, précis or epitome; an abridgement or abstract.
   10. A letter patent, from proper authority, authorizing a collection or charitable contribution of money in churches, for any public or private purpose.
   11. (slang) A ticket of any type.
<verb>
   1. To summarize a recent development to some person with decision-making power.
   2. To write a legal argument and submit it to a court.
<adjective>
   1. Of short duration; happening quickly.
   2. Concise; taking few words.
   3. Occupying a small distance, area or spatial extent; short.
   4. Rife; common; prevalent.
<adverb>
   1. Briefly.
   2. Soon; quickly.
etymology: First recorded in 1250–1300; Middle English bref, from Anglo-French, Old French, from Latin brevis “short”; breve
example: As they moved down the street, Harris waved, held her hand to her heart, and bumped elbows and had brief conversations with several onlookers.

definitionA: to settle (a matter) decisively:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Any of several fastenings.
   2. The act or process of holding fast; that which serves to hold fast; a grip or grasp.
   3. A pun.
   4. A hitch or bend by which a rope is made fast to the ring of an anchor, or the breeching of a ship's gun to the ringbolts.
   5. A passionate embrace.
   6. In combat sports, the act of one or both fighters holding onto the other to prevent being hit or engage in standup grappling.
<verb>
   1. To clasp; to interlock.
   2. To make certain; to finalize.
   3. To fasten securely or permanently.
   4. To bend and hammer the point of (a nail) so it cannot be removed.
   5. To embrace passionately.
   6. To hold firmly; to clench.
   7. To set closely together; to close tightly.
etymology: First recorded in 1560–70; later variant of Middle English clench
example: Notably, a 6-turn clinch knot and a 5-turn improved clinch also came in at 96%, but only if they were tied with extreme care.

definitionA: place; stead.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Place, stead; See in lieu or in lieu of
etymology: First recorded in 1250–1300; from Middle French, from Latin locus “place”; replacing Middle English liue, from Old French liu, from Latin; locus
example: In fitness, we embraced regular leisure walks in lieu of trendy fitness classes.

definitionA: the place of a person or thing as occupied by a successor or substitute:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A place, or spot, in general.
   2. A place where a person normally rests; a seat.
   3. An inhabited place; a settlement, city, town etc.
   4. An estate, a property with its grounds; a farm.
   5. The frame on which a bed is laid; a bedstead.
   6. (in phrases) The position or function (of someone or something), as taken on by a successor.
   7. An emotional or circumstantial "place" having specified advantages, qualities etc. (now only in phrases).
<verb>
   1. To help, support, benefit or assist; to be helpful or noteful.
   2. To fill stead or place of.
<noun>
   1. One's partner in a romantic relationship.
etymology: before 900; (noun) Middle English, Old English stede; cognate with German Stätte place; akin to German Stadt, Old Norse stathr, Gothic staths, Greek stásis ( stasis ); (v.) Middle English steden, derivative of the noun
example: Water Authority board members can designate other members agency to vote in their stead – as a proxy – if they’re absent.

definitionA: diaphragm ( def 1 ).
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The middle section of the human torso, from below the chest to above the waist
etymology: before 1000; Middle English mydryf, Old English midhrif, equivalent to mid ( d ) mid 1 + hrif belly
example: The piece’s top is covered with hivelike ceramic tiles and balanced above an impossibly tiny midriff on stinger-like legs.

definitionA: mere nonsense; foolish talk or ideas.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Nonsense or foolishness.
   2. A decorative object of little value; a trifle or gewgaw.
etymology: First recorded in 1695–1705 and 1820–25  folderol fordef 2; originally as a nonsense refrain in songs; of obscure origin
example: Men and women of good intent who simply seek “the truth” upon which to base their opinions find themselves awash in folderol.

definitionA: dead and putrefying flesh.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Dead flesh; carcasses.
   2. A contemptible or worthless person.
etymology: 1175–1225; Middle English caroyne, careyn, carion < Anglo-French careine, Old French charo ( i ) gne < Vulgar Latin *caronia, equivalent to Latin carun- ( caruncle ) + -ia -y 3
example: Many herbivores will opportunistically scarf down carrion for protein, Gerlach says.

definitionA: capable of being depended on; worthy of trust; reliable:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A reliable person or thing.
<adjective>
   1. Able, or easily able to be depended on.
etymology: First recorded in 1725–35; depend + -able
example: Never, that is, until this fan-free denatured year, with one more of our dependable normal delights subtracted.

definitionA: done, spoken, performed, etc., without special advance preparation; impromptu:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Without preparation or advanced thought; offhand.
etymology: First recorded in 1650–60, from Late Latin extemporāneus “on the spur of the moment”; extempore, -an, -eous
example: Kennedy realizes he’s got to go on television and preempt Wallace, and he does so and gives a largely extemporaneous speech, in which he elevates the civil rights movement to a moral issue.

definitionA: refractory or unruly:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Given to troublemaking.
   2. Irritable; argumentative; quarrelsome.
etymology: First recorded in 1715–25; fracti(on) + -ous
example: The post Google’s delayed cookie cull is an inevitable intermission to its fractious pursuit of privacy protections appeared first on Digiday.

definitionA: lack of the usual comforts or necessaries of life:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The state of being deprived of or lacking an attribute formerly or properly possessed; the loss or absence of such an attribute.
   2. The state of being very poor, and lacking the basic necessities of life.
   3. The act of depriving someone of such basic necessities; deprivation.
   4. Degradation or suspension from an office.
etymology: 1350–1400; Middle English (from Middle French privacion ) from Latin prīvātiōn- (stem of prīvātiō ) “a taking away.” See private, -ion
example: If SpaceX or similar providers are willing, high-speed internet from the sky could be a powerful way to provide connectivity to people or populations suffering the privations of war or authoritarian government.

definitionA: a dead body, especially a human body to be dissected; corpse.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A dead body; especially the corpse of a human to be dissected.
etymology: 1350–1400; Middle English < Latin cadāver dead body, corpse; akin to cadere to fall, perish ( decay, chance )
example: We’ve shown that medical students are disgusted by cadavers.

definitionA: to reflect light with a brilliant, sparkling luster; sparkle with reflected light.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A bright, sparkling light; shininess or brilliance.
   2. A shiny, decorative adornment, sometimes sprinkled on glue to make simple artwork.
   3. Glitz.
<verb>
   1. To sparkle with light; to shine with a brilliant and broken light or showy luster; to gleam.
   2. To be showy, specious, or striking, and hence attractive.
etymology: First recorded in 1300–50; Middle English, from Old Norse glitra; compare Old English glitenian, German gleissen “to shine, glitter”
example: Five hundred of the shells were handmade, designed to explode with twinkling gold glitter and a weeping willow-esque effect.

definitionA: a perch upon which birds or fowls rest at night.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The place where a bird sleeps (usually its nest or a branch).
   2. A group of birds roosting together.
   3. A bedroom
   4. The inner roof of a cottage.
<verb>
   1. (of birds or bats) To settle on a perch in order to sleep or rest
   2. To spend the night
<noun>
   1. A tidal race.
<verb>
   1. To rout out of bed; to rouse
   2. To harass, to treat in a rough way.
   3. To arrest
   4. To drive strongly
etymology: before 1100; Middle English roost (noun), Old English hrōst; cognate with Middle Dutch roest
example: The study showed that the social bonds formed in roosts extended into the hunt.

definitionA: a permanent cardiac or arterial dilatation usually caused by weakening of the vessel wall.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An abnormal blood-filled swelling of an artery or vein, resulting from a localized weakness in the wall of the vessel.
etymology: First recorded in 1650–60; from Greek aneúrysma “dilation,” equivalent to aneurys- (variant stem of aneurýnein “to dilate,” from an- an- 3 + eurýnein “to widen, broaden”; eury- ) + -ma, noun suffix
example: For some patients, it can even go away completely—like it reportedly did after about a week for Game of Thrones star Emilia Clarke, who developed the disorder after having a brain aneurysm.

definitionA: (of an animal) able to subsist on a wide variety of foods.
definitionB: No definition found
etymology: First recorded in 1925–30; eury- + -phagous
example: The crow is euryphagous and, as shown by this study, the diets of crows a few miles apart may differ.

definitionA: any aquatic arthropod of the extinct order Eurypterida, from the Paleozoic Era, closely related to trilobites and scorpions.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A large, prehistoric, carnivorous arthropod, of the class †Eurypterida, thought to be one of the first animals to venture onto land.
etymology: From the New Latin word Eurypteridae, dating back to 1870–75. See eury-, -pterous, -id 2
example: The continuation of the dwindling process, already initiated in the Eurypterid, would easily result in the tentacles of Ammocœtes.

definitionA: contemptibly low, mean, or disreputable:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Marked by low quality; inferior; inadequate.
   2. Raunchy or perverted in nature; tastelessly sexual
   3. Untrustworthy
   4. Thin and flimsy
etymology: First recorded in 1635–45  sleazy fordef 3; of obscure origin; probably unrelated to Silesia; first recorded in 1941  sleazy fordefs 1, 2; perhaps a distinct word
example: Or as Joey, the sleazy, besieged used car salesman in Cadillac Man.

definitionA: to mix in a confused mass; put or throw together without order:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A mixture of unrelated things.
   2. Items for a rummage sale.
   3. A rummage sale.
<verb>
   1. To mix or confuse.
   2. To meet or unite in a confused way.
<noun>
   1. A small, thin, sugared cake, usually ring-shaped.
etymology: 1520–30; perhaps blend of joll to bump (now dial.) and tumble
example: When tested on a jumble of polyethylene, PET and EVOH beads, the solvent washes recovered more than 95 percent of each material — hinting that these solvents could be used to strip plastic components off bulkier items than packaging films.

definitionA: a two-wheeled chariot drawn by four horses harnessed abreast.
definitionB: No definition found
etymology: 1720–30; < Latin quadrīga, earlier plural quadrīgae, contraction of quadrijugae a team of four; quadri-, yoke 1
example: The god is standing upright in his quadriga, conducted by Mercury and holding in his arms the form of Vibia.

definitionA: to ward off (a thrust, stroke, weapon, etc.), as in fencing; avert.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A defensive or deflective action; an act of parrying.
   2. A simple defensive action designed to deflect an attack, performed with the forte of the blade.
   3. (combat sports and martial arts) A defensive move intended to change the direction of an incoming strike to make it miss its intended target, rather than block and absorb it; and typically performed with an open hand in a downward or sideways slapping motion.
<verb>
   1. To avoid, deflect, or ward off (an attack, a blow, an argument, etc.).
etymology: 1665–75; < French parez, imperative of parer to ward off, set off < Latin parāre to set. See parade
example: “There are chances to attack everywhere,” says Parry, who adds that Zwift places great emphasis on designing races for their entertainment value.

definitionA: bustling excitement or activity; commotion; hullabaloo; to-do.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A bustling to-do, excited speech or noise.
   2. A carnival game in which the player attempts to throw hoops around pegs.
etymology: First recorded in 1865–70, hoopla is from the French word houp-là! command (as to a child) to move, take a step
example: We’ve heard very little from Congress in the last two years on energy, despite all of the initial hoopla, and it’s not clear what energy policy is going to look like after the November election.

definitionA: a person employed to write what another dictates or to copy what has been written by another; secretary.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. One employed to take dictation, or copy manuscripts.
   2. A clerk, secretary or stenographer, or scribe.
etymology: 1610–20; < Latin ( servus ) āmanuēnsis, equivalent to ā- a- 4 + manu-, stem of manus hand + -ēnsis -ensis
example: At Newsweek he dueled with his economic nemesis, Paul Samuelson, the amanuensis of the Keynesian revolution.

definitionA: to confuse or fluster.
definitionB: No definition found
etymology: First recorded in 1900–05; origin uncertain; from bum- (as in the initial syllable of Scottish bumbaze, bombaze “to confuse” ( bamboozle ) + fuzzle “to confuse” (perhaps a blend of fuddle and fuzzy ( def ) )

definitionA: distrusting or disparaging the motives of others; like or characteristic of a cynic.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Of or relating to the belief that human actions are motivated only or primarily by base desires or selfishness.
   2. Skeptical of the integrity, sincerity, or motives of others.
   3. Bitterly or jadedly distrustful or contemptuous; mocking.
   4. Showing contempt for accepted moral standards by one's actions.
   5. Like the actions of a snarling dog, especially in reference to facial nerve paralysis.
etymology: First recorded in 1580–90; cynic + -al 1
example: He writes that criticism of his performance on nursing homes was the organized and cynical work of Republicans looking to avoid accountability for their own failures in the face of the crisis.

definitionA: to deceive or get the better of (someone) by trickery, flattery, or the like; humbug; hoodwink (often followed by into ):
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To con, defraud, trick, to make a fool of, to humbug or impose on someone.
   2. To confuse, frustrate or perplex.
etymology: First recorded in 1695–1705; origin uncertain
example: “To find out I had to sit out, that’s when I kind of felt bamboozled, because y’all told me to go,” he said, adding that he “absolutely” would not have taken the trip had he known it would cause him to miss five days of practice.

definitionA: Nautical.  a drain at the edge of a deck exposed to the weather, for allowing accumulated water to drain away into the sea or into the bilges. Compare freeing port.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A drainage hole on the deck of a ship.
   2. A similar opening in a wall or parapet that allows water to drain from a roof.
<verb>
   1. Thwart or destroy, especially something belonging or pertaining to another; compare scuttle.
etymology: First recorded in 1475–85; Middle English skopor, scopper; further origin uncertain
example: That action has scuppered some of the IAB-backed group’s plans.

definitionA: the arrangement of veins, as in a leaf or in the wing of an insect.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The hunting of wild animals.
<noun>
   1. The arrangement of veins in a leaf, wing, or similar structure.
etymology: 1640–50; < Latin vēn ( a ) vein + -ation
example: The venation is peculiar, and the disposition of the sori depends mainly on the peculiarities of the venation.

definitionA: to deprive (a woman) of virginity.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To take the virginity of (somebody), especially a woman or girl.
   2. To deprive of flowers.
   3. To deprive of grace and beauty.
etymology: 1350–1400; Middle English deflouren < Old French desflorer < Latin dēflōrāre, equivalent to dē- de- + flōr-, stem of flōs flower + -āre infinitive suffix
example: Individual inspiration was a sacred thing, which reality with its rules and prejudices could only spoil and deflower.

definitionA: the gratification of sexual desire.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The hunting of wild animals.
   2. Game animals.
<noun>
   1. The pursuit of sexual pleasure or indulgence.
etymology: 1490–1500; < Latin vener- (stem of venus; Venus ) + -y 3; compare Latin venera amours
example: The venery was a little further off, drawing toward the park.

definitionA: of or relating to a royal court.
definitionB: No definition found
etymology: 1695–1705; < Latin aulicus < Greek aulikós courtly, equivalent to aul ( ḗ ) hall, court + -ikos -ic
example: He had to go; and occupy himself complaining, soliciting Aulic-Councils and the like, for therest of his life.

definitionA: to regard or treat with reverence; revere.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To treat with great respect and deference.
   2. To revere or hold in awe.
etymology: 1615–25; < Latin venerātus, past participle of venerārī to solicit the goodwill of (a god), worship, revere, verbal derivative of vener-, stem of venus, presumably in its original sense “desire”; Venus )
example: The coach, a guest, venerates the stranger, who’s presumably a member, saying how he’d like to teach Howard golfers as much about the game that the older man has already forgotten.

definitionA: arising from, connected with, or transmitted through sexual intercourse, as an infection.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Of or relating to the genitals or sexual intercourse.
   2. Of a disease: sexually transmitted; of or relating to, or adapted to the cure of, a venereal disease.
   3. Pertaining to the astrological influence of the planet Venus; lascivious, lustful.
   4. Of or relating to copper (formerly called Venus by alchemists).
etymology: 1400–50; late Middle English < Latin venere ( us ) of sexual love ( vener-, stem of venus sexual charm ( Venus ) + -eus adj. suffix) + -al 1
example: Conservatives on Twitter howl derisively at these polls as if their purveyors are offering alchemical cures for venereal disease.

definitionA: able to be forgiven or pardoned; not seriously wrong, as a sin ( mortal ).
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Pardonable; able to be forgiven.
   2. Excusable; trifling
etymology: 1250–1300; Middle English < Medieval Latin veniālis, equivalent to Latin veni ( a ) grace, favor, indulgence (akin to venus; venerate, Venus ) + -ālis -al 1
example: Conventionality is the most venial of all moviemaking sins, if it’s a sin at all.

definitionA: to think; suppose.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Doubt; conjecture.
<verb>
   1. To suppose, imagine; to think, believe.
   2. To expect, hope or wish.
<verb>
   1. To weep or cry.
   2. To lament.
etymology: before 900; Middle English wenen, Old English wēnan to expect; cognate with German wähnen to imagine, Old Norse væna, Gothic wēnjan to hope, expect
example: The use of ween is limited; and the third person, singular and plural, is generally indicated by the sign, O.

definitionA: a character (ƿ) representing the sound (w) in Old English and early Middle English manuscripts, based on a rune with the same phonetic value.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A letter of the Old English alphabet, borrowed from the futhark and used to represent the sound of w; replaced in Middle English times by the digraph uu, which later developed into the letter w.
<noun>
   1. A kind of timber truck, or carriage.
etymology: before 1100; Middle English wen, Old English wyn ( n ), special use of wyn ( n ) joy ( winsome, wish )
example: “No, the Second Amendment is exceptional not because it is uniquely oppressed or imperiled, but rather because it is singularly capable of causing harm,” wrote Wynn, a nominee of President Barack Obama.

definitionA: accustomed; used (usually followed by an infinitive):
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. One's habitual way of doing things; custom, habit, practice.
<verb>
   1. To make (someone) used to; to accustom.
   2. To be accustomed (to something), to be in the habit (of doing something).
<adjective>
   1. Accustomed or used (to or with a thing), accustomed or apt (to do something).
etymology: irst recorded in 1300–50; (adjective) Middle English wont, woned, Old English gewunod, past participle of gewunian “to be used to” ( won 2 ); cognate with German gewöhnt; (verb) Middle English, back formation from wonted or wont (past participle); (noun) apparently from conflation of wont (past participle) with obsolete wone “wish” in certain stereotyped phrases
example: Forgive my candor, though such is my wont, but much like that moose on a spit, Bernie is dead.

definitionA: without interest, vigor, or determination; listless; halfhearted:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Showing no interest, vigor, determination, or enthusiasm.
   2. Lazy; slothful; indolent.
etymology: irst recorded in 1760–70; lackadais(y) (variant of lackaday ) + -ical
example: Their defense is lackadaisical, their forwards frequently inept.

definitionA: lacking force, brilliance, or vitality
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Lack of brightness or points of interest.
   2. A person or thing of no particular brilliance or intelligence.
<adjective>
   1. Lacking brilliance or intelligence.
   2. Having no shine or lustre; dull.
   3. Not exceptional; not worthy of special merit, attention, or interest; having no vitality.
example: Pippa Middleton has parted company with her literary agent following the lacklustre reception to her first book.

definitionA: a state of intense happiness and self-confidence:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An excited state of joy; a feeling of intense happiness.
etymology: irst recorded in 1880–85; from New Latin, from Greek euphoría “state of well-being”; eu-, -phore, -ia
example: “She was tireless and often seemed in a state of euphoria,” Pausini told police, according to the documents.

definitionA: to sharpen (a knife, tool, etc.) by grinding or friction.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The act of whetting something.
   2. That which whets or sharpens; especially, an appetizer.
<verb>
   1. To hone or rub on with some substance, as a piece of stone, for the purpose of sharpening – see whetstone.
   2. To stimulate or make more keen.
   3. To preen.
etymology: before 900; Middle English whetten (v.), Old English hwettan (derivative of hwæt bold); cognate with German wetzen, Old Norse hvetja, Gothic gahwatjan to incite
example: To whet your appetite, you can relive that glorious moment (and watch other programs from the 2014 summit) here.

definitionA: of or relating to an uncle:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. In the manner of an uncle, pertaining to an uncle.
   2. (by extension) Kind, genial, benevolent, or tolerant.
etymology: First recorded in 1825–35; from Latin avuncul(us) “a mother's brother,” equivalent to av(us) “a forefather” + unattested -ont- + unattested -l(os) diminutive suffix ( uncle ) + -ar 1
example: There’s a world of difference between Lindell, with his conspiracy theory-fuelled, feverish pleading for those in power to take his claims seriously, and Cuffe’s avuncular small-town sincerity.

definitionA: a hair highlighting technique in which dye is painted onto the hair to lighten it in a natural-looking way.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A hair colouring technique in which colour is applied by hand.
   2. A method for reconstructing a harmonic function
etymology: First recorded in 1975–80; from French: literally, “sweeping,” derivative of verb balayer, from Middle French, Old French balaier, derivative of French balai, from Old French balei, baleis “a broom, brush,” alteration (influenced by balier, baloier “to move about excitedly”) of Late Latin ballāre “to dance”; ball 2( def )

definitionA: of, relating to, or affected with lethargy; drowsy; sluggish; apathetic.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Sluggish, slow
   2. Indifferent, apathetic
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; from Latin lēthargicus, from Greek lēthargikós; replacing Middle English litargik, from Medieval Latin litargicus ( lethargy, -ic )
example: He’s an ideal companion — “my mentor, my Yoda,” as Fox puts it — and the antidote to Marty’s lethargic, risk-adverse parents.

definitionA: a Spanish opera having spoken dialogue and often a satirically treated, topical theme.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A form of Spanish opera having spoken dialogue and usually a comic subject.
etymology: 1885–90; < Spanish, after La Zarzuela, palace near Madrid where first performance took place (1629)
example: The last-named type, the zarzuela, became particularly popular.

definitionA: a small stream; streamlet; brook.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A small brook or stream; a streamlet.
   2. Perizoma affinitatum, a geometrid moth.
etymology: 1580–90; earlier rivolet < Italian rivoletto, diminutive of rivolo < Latin rīvulus small stream
example: This was one saucy sandwich, and I immediately imagined myself with rivulets of both of its dressings dripping down my chin.

definitionA: subject to, led by, or indicative of a sudden, odd notion or unpredictable change; erratic:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Impulsive and unpredictable; determined by chance, impulse, or whim
etymology: First recorded in 1585–95; from French capricieux, from Italian capriccioso capriccioso
example: Like every other capricious pillar of global capital in the world, the IOC insists that their giant money-printing operation is actually a bringer of peace and progress—a harbor for an open world that spreads democracy far and wide.

definitionA: to rid of whatever is impure or undesirable; cleanse; purify:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An act of purging.
   2. An evacuation of the bowels or a vomiting.
   3. A cleansing of pipes.
   4. A forcible removal of people, for example, from political activity.
   5. That which purges; especially, a medicine that evacuates the intestines; a cathartic.
<verb>
   1. To clean thoroughly; to cleanse; to rid of impurities.
   2. To free from sin, guilt, or the burden or responsibility of misdeeds
   3. To remove by cleansing; to wash away.
   4. To void or evacuate (the bowels or the stomach); to defecate or vomit.
   5. To cause someone to purge, operate on (somebody) as or with a cathartic or emetic, or in a similar manner.
   6. To clear of a charge, suspicion, or imputation
   7. To clarify; to clear the dregs from (liquor).
   8. To become pure, as by clarification.
   9. To have or produce frequent evacuations from the intestines, as by means of a cathartic.
   10. To trim, dress or prune.
etymology: First recorded in 1250–1300; (verb) Middle English purgen, from Old French purg(i)er, from Latin pūrgāre “to cleanse”; (noun) Middle English, from Old French, derivative of the verb
example: The members alleged an ideological purge of the party, given most of them were aligned with the tea party.

definitionA: a period or bout, usually brief, of excessive indulgence, as in eating, drinking alcoholic beverages, etc.; spree.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A short period of excessive consumption, especially of food, alcohol, narcotics, etc.
   2. (by extension) A short period of an activity done in excess, such as watching a television show.
<verb>
   1. To engage in a short period of excessive consumption, especially of excessive alcohol consumption.
etymology: First recorded in 1850–55; dialectal (Lincolnshire) binge “to soak”; further origin unknown
example: Of course, those nightly Internet binges were not without misdirection.

definitionA: Psychiatry. anorexia nervosa.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Loss of appetite, especially as a result of disease.
   2. Anorexia nervosa.
etymology: First recorded in 1590–1600; from New Latin, from Greek, from an- an- 1 + órex(is) “appetite, desire, longing” (from orég(ein) “to reach, stretch” + -sis -sis ) + -ia -ia
example: Gender is also a factor in eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa, which is three times as prevalent among women as men.

definitionA: to convert into or regard as a concrete thing:
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To regard something abstract as if it were a concrete material thing
etymology: First recorded in 1850–55; from Latin rē(s) “thing” + -ify
example: It would reify the division between Israelis living within the Green Line and those living beyond it.

definitionA: to claim unwarrantably or presumptuously; assume or appropriate to oneself without right:
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To appropriate or lay claim to something for oneself without right.
etymology: 1530–40; < Latin arrogātus appropriated, assumed, questioned (past participle of arrogāre ), equivalent to arrog- ( ar- ar- + rog ( āre ) to ask, propose) + -ātus -ate 1
example: And so they try to arrogate my medical authority for their cause.

definitionA: of or relating to desire; appetitive.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Of or pertaining to desire or appetite
etymology: 1665–75; < Greek orektikós appetitive, equivalent to orekt(ós) stretched out, longed for (derivative of orégein to grasp for, desire) + -ikos -ic
example: Associated words: desiderative, desideratum, orectic, optative.

definitionA: to make, put, or set right; remedy; correct:
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To heal (an organ or part of the body).
   2. To restore (someone or something) to its proper condition; to straighten out, to set right.
   3. To remedy or fix (an undesirable state of affairs, situation etc.).
   4. To purify or refine (a substance) by distillation.
   5. To correct or amend (a mistake, defect etc.).
   6. To correct (someone who is mistaken).
   7. (geodesy) To adjust (a globe or sundial) to prepare for the solution of a proposed problem.
   8. To convert (alternating current) into direct current.
   9. To determine the length of a curve included between two limits.
   10. To produce (as factitious gin or brandy) by redistilling bad wines or strong spirits (whisky, rum, etc.) with flavourings.
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; Middle English rectifien, from Middle French rectifier, from Medieval Latin rēctificāre, from Latin rēct(us) “right, straight” + -ificāre -ify; right
example: City real estate professionals moved on this year amid the controversy, and city taxpayers will continue to be on the hook for the millions of dollars associated with rectifying them.

definitionA: forming a straight line.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. In a straight line.
   2. Formed from straight lines.
etymology: 1650–60; < Late Latin rēctilīne ( us ) ( rēcti- recti- + līne ( a ) line 1 + -us adj. suffix) + -ar 1
example: It shows a boy, not looking where he’s going, head in a book, as he travels from a mostly rectilinear and geometric landscape to a riot of twisted and abstract forms, reminiscent of seas and forest floors and other worlds.

definitionA: rightness of principle or conduct; moral virtue:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Straightness; the state or quality of having a constant direction and not being crooked or bent.
   2. The fact or quality of being right or correct; correctness of opinion or judgement.
   3. Conformity to the rules prescribed for moral conduct; (moral) uprightness, virtue.
etymology: First recorded in 1400–50; late Middle English, from Middle French rectitude, “honesty,” from Late Latin rēctitūdin- (stem of rēctitūdō “straightness, upright posture, honesty, justice”), equivalent to Latin rēct(us) right + -tūdin- -tude
example: That was true most dramatically for New York City in the 1970s, though other cities such as Detroit and Chicago were hardly models of fiscal rectitude.

definitionA: an exclusive right, privilege, etc., exercised by virtue of rank, office, or the like:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A hereditary or official right or privilege.
   2. A right, or power that is exclusive to a monarch etc, especially such a power to make a decision or judgement.
   3. A right, especially when due to one's position or role.
   4. A property, attribute or ability which gives one a superiority or advantage over others; an inherent advantage or privilege; a talent.
<adjective>
   1. Having a hereditary or official right or privilege.
etymology: First recorded in 1350–1400; Middle English, from Latin praerogātīvus (adjective) “voting first,” praerogātīva (noun use of feminine of adjective) “tribe or century with right to vote first.” See pre-, interrogative
example: There’s got to be a better way for the city to register community engagement, even while duly elected representatives retain their voting prerogative.

definitionA: to ask questions of (a person), sometimes to seek answers or information that the person questioned considers personal or secret.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To question or quiz, especially in a thorough and/or aggressive manner
   2. To query; to request information from.
   3. To examine critically.
etymology: First recorded in 1475–85; from Latin interrogātus, past participle of interrogāre “to question, examine,” equivalent to inter- “between, among, together” + rogā(re) “to ask” + -tus past participle suffix; inter-
example: People love the creative storytelling aspect of the game and the strategy behind sounding believable or interrogating someone for the truth.

definitionA: to detract, as from authority, estimation, etc. (usually followed by from ).
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To partially repeal (a law etc.).
   2. To detract from (something); to disparage, belittle.
   3. To take away (something from something else) in a way which leaves it lessened.
   4. To remove a part, to detract from (a quality of excellence, authority etc.).
   5. To act in a manner below oneself; to debase oneself.
<adjective>
   1. Debased
etymology: First recorded in 1375–1425; late Middle English from Latin dērogātus “repealed, restricted” (past participle of dērogāre ), equivalent to dē- de- + rog(āre) “to ask” + -ātus -ate 1
example: Bulgaria cannot rely on its national and constitutional identity and public order to derogate from the fundamental rights of EU citizens.

definitionA: the cry of a goose.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The sound produced by a typical car horn.
   2. The cry of a goose.
   3. A bad smell.
<verb>
   1. To use a car horn.
   2. To make a loud, harsh sound like a car horn.
   3. To make the vocal sound of a goose.
   4. To vomit: regurgitate the contents of one's stomach.
   5. To have a bad smell.
   6. To squeeze playfully, usually a breast or nose.
<interjection>
   1. Imitation of car horn, used, for example, to clear a path for oneself.
<noun>
   1. (racial slur) A Caucasian person.
   2. A factory hand or general unskilled worker.
etymology: An Americanism dating back to 1790–1800; imitative
example: It’s a booming track that hurtles brass instrumentals, car honks and metallic clangs at the listener as the members bulldoze their way from beginning to end.

definitionA: the act of departing from the right, normal, or usual course:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The act of wandering; deviation from truth, moral rectitude; abnormal; divergence from the straight, correct, proper, normal, or from the natural state.
   2. The convergence to different foci, by a lens or mirror, of rays of light emanating from one and the same point, or the deviation of such rays from a single focus; a defect in a focusing mechanism that prevents the intended focal point.
   3. A small periodical change of position in the stars and other heavenly bodies, due to the combined effect of the motion of light and the motion of the observer.
   4. A partial alienation of reason.
   5. A mental disorder, especially one of a minor or temporary character.
   6. Atypical development or structure; deviation from the normal type; an aberrant organ.
   7. A deviation of a tissue, organ or mental functions from what is considered to be within the normal range.
etymology: First recorded in 1585–95; from Latin aberrātiōn-, stem of aberrātiō “distraction, diversion, relief (from pain or sorrow),” from aberrāt(us) “diverted, deviated” (past participle of aberrāre “to divert, forget for a time,” also “to wander, deviate”; aberrant ) + -iō -ion
example: They were also an aberration from conventional music industry logic.

definitionA: to strike forcibly with an ax, sword, or other cutting instrument; chop; hack.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To chop away at; to whittle down; to mow down.
   2. To shape; to form.
   3. To act according to, to conform to; usually construed with to.
<noun>
   1. Hue; colour
   2. Shape; form
   3. Destruction by cutting down.
etymology: First recorded before 900; Middle English hewen, Old English hēawan; cognate with German hauen, Old Norse hǫggva; akin to haggle
example: That system weakened as members of all three branches hewed increasingly to the platforms of the two political parties.

definitionA: having a stale smell; moldy; musty:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Moldy or musty.
   2. Stale-smelling or stuffy.
   3. (by extension) Old-fashioned, refusing to change or update.
   4. (of wine) Tasting of the cask.
etymology: 1350–1400; Middle English fusti, equivalent to fust (noun) < Old French: wine cask, tree trunk (< Latin fūstis stick, pole) + -y 1
example: While they’ve mostly shed their fusty reputation, documentaries still give the impression of being more nutritious than the average TV treat.

definitionA: having an odor or flavor suggestive of mold, as old buildings, long-closed rooms, or stale food.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Having a stale odor.
etymology: 1520–30; perhaps variant of moisty ( Middle English; moist, -y 1 ) with loss of i before s as in master
example: The musty Conservative Party of Margaret Thatcher was in decline, to be replaced the following year by the sterile charm of Tony Blair and his New Labour project.

definitionA: a bitter, sharply abusive denunciation, attack, or criticism:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An abusive, bitter, attack or criticism: denunciation.
   2. A prolonged discourse.
   3. A speech or writing which bitterly denounces something.
etymology: 1575–85; < Latin diatriba < Greek diatribḗ pastime, study, discourse, derivative of diatríbein to rub away ( dia- dia- + tríbein to rub)
example: In its latest diatribe, Amazon spends over six of eight pages on matters wholly irrelevant to the current proceeding or even matters currently before the commission.

definitionA: to make holy; sanctify; consecrate.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. (obsolete outside set phrases) A saint; a holy person; an apostle.
<verb>
   1. To make holy, to sanctify.
<noun>
   1. A shout, cry; a hulloo.
<verb>
   1. To shout, especially to urge on dogs for hunting.
<adjective>
   1. (of something solid) Having an empty space or cavity inside.
   2. (of a sound) Distant, eerie; echoing, reverberating, as if in a hollow space; dull, muffled; often low-pitched.
   3. Without substance; having no real or significant worth; meaningless.
   4. Insincere, devoid of validity; specious.
   5. Concave; gaunt; sunken.
   6. Pertaining to hollow body position
etymology: First recorded before 900; Middle English hal(o)wen, Old English hālgian (cognate with German heiligen, Old Norse helga ), derivative of hālig “consecrated, sacred, holy”; holy
example: To live with ugliness, we must hallow loveliness the more, remembering that it often springsfrom mud into light-filled air.

definitionA: to cudgel; beat; punish severely.
definitionB: No definition found
etymology: First recorded in 1650–60; from Late Latin fūstīgātus, past participle of fūstigāre “to cudgel to death,” derivative of the noun fūstis “a stick, club, cudgel” + -igāre, combining form of agere “to drive, do, act”

definitionA: to explode with a loud noise; detonate.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Any salt or ester of fulminic acid, mostly explosive.
<verb>
   1. To make a verbal attack.
   2. To issue as a denunciation.
   3. To thunder or make a loud noise.
   4. To strike with lightning; to cause to explode.
etymology: First recorded in 1375–1425; late Middle English fulminaten < Latin fulminātus, past participle of fulmināre “to hurl thunderbolts, thunder,” equivalent to fulmin-, stem of fulmen “thunderbolt, lightning” + -ātus -ate 1
example: The gun nuts—and obviously, not all gun owners are nuts, not even a majority—fulminate endlessly about their rights.

definitionA: to expose to smoke or fumes, as in disinfecting or exterminating roaches, ants, etc.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To disinfect, purify, or rid of vermin with the fumes of certain chemicals.
etymology: First recorded in 1520–30; from Latin fūmigātus, past participle of fūmigāre “to smoke, fumigate,” equivalent to fūm(us) “smoke” + -igāre, combining form of agere “to drive, do”
example: The facilities use a toxic gas called ethylene oxide to sanitize medical and dental equipment and fumigate certain food products.

definitionA: busy activity or bustle; fuss; bother:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Trouble; troublesome business; fuss, commotion
etymology: First recorded in 1250–1300; Middle English (north) at do, a phrase equivalent to at “to” (from Old Norse, which used at with the infinitive) + do do 1
example: So without further ado, here’s a smattering of dogs — and birds, and squirrels — filling up while the filling’s good.

definitionA: to soil; tarnish; discolor.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To make dirty.
   2. To tarnish something, especially someone's reputation.
etymology: First recorded in 1590–1600; be- + smirch
example: While Couric included some of Ginsburg’s criticism in the finished product, she decided to leave out that particular barb, concerned that it would besmirch the reputation of someone she was a “fan” of.

definitionA: to discolor or soil; spot or smudge with or as with soot, dust, dirt, etc.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Dirt, or a stain.
   2. A stain on somebody's reputation.
<verb>
   1. To dirty; to make dirty.
   2. To harm the reputation of; to smear or slander.
<noun>
   1. A chirp of radiation power from an astronomical body that has a smeared appearance on its plot in the time-frequency plane (usually associated with massive bodies orbiting supermassive black holes)
etymology: First recorded in 1485–95; origin uncertain
example: After the trial I saw Holker and asked him if he had been helping to smirch any more poor artists.

definitionA: a person who knowingly helps another in a crime or wrongdoing, often as a subordinate.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. An associate in the commission of a crime; a participator in an offense, whether a principal or an accessory.
   2. A cooperator.
etymology: First recorded in 1475–85; a(c) of uncertain origin + late Middle English complice, from Middle French, from Medieval Latin complici- (stem of complex ) “partner”; complex
example: The information will be stored in a confidential database accessible to federal law enforcement and shared with banks who are often unwitting accomplices to international corruption.

definitionA: an utterance or discourse spoken to oneself, without regard for whether any other hearers are present (often used as a device in drama to disclose a character's innermost thoughts):
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. The act of a character speaking to themselves so as to reveal their thoughts to the audience.
   2. (authorship) A speech or written discourse in this form.
<verb>
   1. (very rare) To issue a soliloquy.
etymology: First recorded in 1595–1605; from Late Latin sōliloquium “a talking to oneself, soliloquy,” equivalent to sōli- soli- 1 + loqu(ī) “to speak” + -ium -ium; -y 3

definitionA: a state of dissatisfaction, anxiety, or restlessness:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A state of feeling unwell or unhappy; a feeling of emotional and mental discomfort and suffering from restlessness, malaise, depression or anxiety.
etymology: First recorded in 1835–45; from New Latin, from Greek dysphoría “malaise, discomfort,” equivalent to dys- dys- + phor(ós) “bearing” + -ia -ia
example: Gender dysphoria is a serious medical condition, and for incarcerated people it means the Constitution requires they be provided with adequate health care.

definitionA: to agree or concur; subscribe to (often followed by to ):
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. Agreement; act of agreeing
<verb>
   1. To agree; to give approval.
   2. To admit a thing as true.
etymology: 1250–1300; Middle English asenten < Old French asenter < Latin assentārī, equivalent to as- as- + sen ( t )- ( scent ) + -t- frequentative suffix + -ā- thematic vowel + -rī infinitive suffix
example: She gave royal assent to the Sexual Offenses Act of 1967, which decriminalized consensual same-sex sexual relations among men in England and Wales who are at least 21, as the Blade reported.

definitionA: a slight, superficial, or introductory knowledge of something:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A superficial or shallow knowledge of a subject.
   2. A small number or amount of something.
<verb>
   1. To talk superficially; to babble, chatter.
   2. To speak (a language) with spotty or superficial knowledge.
   3. To study or approach superficially; to dabble in.
   4. To have a slight taste, or a slight, superficial knowledge, of anything; to smack.
etymology: First recorded in 1530–40; smatter + -ing 1( def ).
example: At first, just a smattering of travelers tested positive, triggering work-from-home orders and panicked searches for masks.

definitionA: bare, desolate, and often windswept:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Without color; pale; pallid.
   2. Desolate and exposed; swept by cold winds.
   3. Unhappy; cheerless; miserable; emotionally desolate.
<noun>
   1. A small European river fish (Alburnus alburnus), of the family Cyprinidae.
etymology: First recorded in 1300–50; Middle English bleke “pale,” blend of variants bleche ( Old English blǣc ) and blake ( Old English blāc ); both cognate with Old Norse bleikr, German bleich; akin to bleach
example: It was a bleak image of the future, with an urgent call to action — one that was more or less ignored by the federal government.

definitionA: a long, narrow, open receptacle, usually boxlike in shape, used chiefly to hold water or food for animals.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A long, narrow container, open on top, for feeding or watering animals.
   2. Any similarly shaped container.
   3. A short, narrow canal designed to hold water until it drains or evaporates.
   4. A gutter under the eaves of a building; an eaves trough.
   5. A channel for conveying water or other farm liquids (such as milk) from place to place by gravity; any ‘U’ or ‘V’ cross-sectioned irrigation channel.
   6. A long, narrow depression between waves or ridges; the low portion of a wave cycle.
   7. A linear atmospheric depression associated with a weather front.
<verb>
   1. To eat in a vulgar style, as if from a trough.
etymology: First recorded before 900; Middle English; Old English trōh; cognate with Dutch, German, Old Norse trog
example: Cooler air in the core of the trough aloft will help destabilize the atmosphere, and increase the winds in middle levels of the atmosphere.

definitionA: distinct in kind; essentially different; dissimilar:
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. (chiefly in the plural) Any of a group of unequal or dissimilar things.
<adjective>
   1. Composed of inherently different or distinct elements; incongruous.
   2. Essentially different; of different species, unlike but not opposed in pairs; also, less properly, utterly unlike; incapable of being compared; having no common genus.
etymology: First recorded in 1580–90; from Latin disparātus “separated,” past participle of disparāre “to separate,” from dis- dis- 1 + parāre “to make ready” ( pare )

definitionA: to impair the quality of; make faulty; spoil.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To spoil, make faulty; to reduce the value, quality, or effectiveness of something
   2. To debase or morally corrupt
   3. To violate, to rape
   4. To make something ineffective, to invalidate
etymology: First recorded in 1525–35; from Latin vitiātus, past participle of vitiāre “to spoil, impair,” derivative of vitium “blemish, defect, fault” + -ātus; vice 1, -ate 1
example: The result will be provisions that are watered down or loopholes that vitiate key provisions altogether.

definitionA: pertaining to, of the nature of, or caused by an earthquake or vibration of the earth, whether due to natural or artificial causes.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Related to, or caused by an earthquake or other vibration of the Earth.
   2. Of very large or widespread effect.
etymology: First recorded in 1855–60; seism + -ic
example: Previous studies have noted that CO2 tends to escape Earth in seismic hot spots.

definitionA: the quality of being fragrant; a sweet or pleasing scent.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A pleasant smell or odour.
<verb>
   1. To apply a fragrance to; to perfume.
etymology: First recorded in 1660–70; from French, from Late Latin frāgrantia. See fragrant, -ance

definitionA: first in place, order, rank, etc.:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. First, either in time or in space
   2. Most forward; front
   3. Of a higher rank or position; paramount
   4. Closest to the bow
<adverb>
   1. In front
   2. Prominently forward
   3. Especially; particularly
etymology: before 1000; fore 1 + -most; replacing Middle English, Old English formest, equivalent to form ( a ) first, variant of fruma (compare Latin prīmus ) + -est -est 1

definitionA: to pretend illness, especially in order to shirk one's duty, avoid work, etc.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To feign illness, injury, or incapacitation in order to avoid work, obligation, or perilous risk.
   2. To self-inflict real injury or infection (to inflict self-harm) in order to avoid work, obligation, or perilous risk.
etymology: First recorded in 1810–20; from French malingre “sickly, ailing,” equivalent to mal- “bad, ill” + Old French heingre “haggard” (perhaps from Germanic ); mal-
example: It was quick work; but Bowles had a college education—he had been only six hours a cowboy when he learned to malinger on the job.

definitionA: out of the ordinary course of nature; exceptional or abnormal:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Beyond or not conforming to what is natural or according to the regular course of things; strange.
   2. Having an existence outside of the natural world.
etymology: First recorded in 1570–80; from Medieval Latin praeternātūrālis, adjective based on Latin phrase praeter nātūram “beyond nature”; preter-, natural
example: An activist conservative and preternatural salesman, he drew national attention for his work on health care and welfare policy.

definitionA: in English, the simple past, or an instance or form of a specific verb in the simple past, such as ate or walked.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. (grammar) The preterite tense, simple past tense: the grammatical tense that determines the specific initiation or termination of an action in the past.
<adjective>
   1. (grammar, of a tense) showing an action at a determined moment in the past.
   2. Belonging wholly to the past; passed by.
